title: How are songs recorded in a studio? - Quora

response.answer_text: I have recorded over 100 songs and the amount of time varies depending on the song. I have recorded songs in as little as an hour and have taken the whole day on others. It depends a lot on the arrangement and just how prepared you are. It also depends on just how good the people you are working with are. Just to demonstrate what I mean while recording in Hawaii the studio I used my co-producer and sound engineer was also a fantastic musician. in a 2 hour period we were able to have him do a keyboard part, piano part and drum part where I did the bass and guitar parts and then record the vocals. The song was a 4 minute song but being able to lay down 5 instrument tracks and not only the lead vocals but also the backing vocals in that amount of time was fantastic. We were able to accomplish this because Pierre was so good at his job. I’ve done similar recording in New Mexico because the studio I used there the guy was also very talented. I did a song that was only an acoustic guitar and my vocals and we did that song in less than an hour. I recorded at the Sound Factory and it was so time consuming at times and it could take pretty much all day to do a song. The biggest difference was the fact the guy I was working with was not a musician as well as being a sound engineer so it took time to get the song the way I wanted it. When I recorded in Manila, Philippines the studio there the guy was just so anal I laid down my tracks and came back about 8 hours later and I really wasn’t happy with the end product so I should have stayed and made sure I got what I wanted but the guy had done the production for Crosby, Stills and Nash so I figured he had to be good. Bottom line is that there are so many factors you have to take into consideration that there is no black and white answer to your question.

I think the strangest part of it is that it doesn’t *feel* like a long time. But that doesn’t answer your question. Modern recording is about perfection. To the extent possible we want to get a perfect recording, but we can go back later and touch up (think Photoshop for audio) the little imperfections that arise. That means recording each track separately - drums, guitar, bass, vocals, etc. The more there is the longer it’ll take. I had my niece in the studio last summer for a couple of simple Christmas songs that were mainly her voice + acoustic guitar. We added bass and drums later. Just to get her and the guitar recorded took about 4 hours per song. The first hour was spent going through the music, getting down the chord progressions that we would use (she’s rather jazzy so regular chords are boring), lyrics, all that stuff. This would culminate in sitting around playing guitar and singing the entire song. After that it was another 30–45 minutes to get the guitar part recorded perfectly, recording it perhaps 10 times. This usually included a few “oh crap” moments when we would start over. After that it’s time to sing. Thankfully these were single vocal with no background vocals. We would spend an hour to an hour and a half with her singing. Repeatedly. There were a few “oh crap” moments there as well, but it’s quite easy to just restart at the beginning of a phrase and continue. Sometimes the last take is mainly the one we use. The producer helps her with suggestions (“pour on the sweetness on this take”, “let’s be a little subdued”, etc.) so that he can mix and match later. After all that it’s time to put together the guitar + vocal version that will be the foundation for whatever else we might do with the song. So the producer (this is small studio) goes through piece by piece for another hour to hour and a half and listens to each vocal, marking for each phrase which his favorites are. After that we go back through and piece together the whole song based on our favorite pieces. Again, this process would be much much longer for a recording with a whole band. At this point, he fixes up any bad pitches, silences the vocals between phrases, etc. When he finishes we have a good recording. Now, he goes back through and adds a bass line and percussion. Often we just use recorded instruments for this (hard to explain until you see it, but they sound great). This part is actually easier than the rest of it. Now, that’s for a song that’ll have four tracks total at the end: guitar, vocal, bass, percussion. Your normal pop song will have 10+ tracks between all instruments and vocals. Scale this up accordingly.

Very generic question, for there are myriads of ways to create a recording. I'll keep it simple though.A singer/songwriter with a guitar only needs two microphones: one for the voice, one for the guitar - although most studio's might use two for the guitar, to get a  stereo recording.If it is a fullblown popsong, then instruments may be played by professional session musicians (for solo artists/vocalists) or by the members of the band.Or, the whole arrangement may be made by one person using the MIDI (Musical Instrument Digital Interface) protocol. This is how most modern popsongs and filmscores are created, by just one or two persons - think of AVICII, Daft Punk, Royksopp, Aphex Twin, Moby and many, many more.MIDI enables a musician to trigger sounds via any controller that can send MIDI, such as a MIDI-keyboard, or MIDI-drums, or a MIDI-guitar or a MIDI wind-controller. None of these controller make sounds, they just send performance info to a soundmodule (which can be standalone hardware or a soundlibrary on a computer), and that module then produces the sound.When I hit a key on my MIDI-keyboard, two pieces of MIDI information are sent to the computer or soundmodule: the "type" of event (note on) and the velocity (power) with which the key is pressed (value between 1 amd 127). If I release the key a "note off" message is sent. When recording MIDI, the length of a note is the time between note on and note off.In the recording program (known as DAW (Digital Audio Workstation)) you can see this MIDI info in the Piano Roll. MIDI in Logic Pro X   In a DAW, besides MIDI, you can also directly record audio - just like on a taperecorder in the analog days. So that is why you see both audio and MIDI in any DAW. The DAW (in this case Logic Pro X) will contain the complete song.  Audio in Logic Pro X  The big advantage of this way of production is firstly  that MIDI is, the only digital protocol (since 1981!) for musical performance data, there are no other protocols, so there's never any mismatch with hardware or software. The second big advantage is that digital audio is now of a much better potential quality then analog recording ever was, even though there is still a perception bias of it being harsh. This is no longer true, in spite of what "analog believers" will try to tell you. I can make digital audio that even a blind audio engineer will not be able to tell apart from taperecorded (= analog) audio. Here is my (strictly amateur) rendition of this old Randy Newman song. Rain Today

I have been playing in the most advanced youth orchestra in the state of Utah for a little over a year. This orchestra likes to record YouTube videos and songs throughout the year all as a way to spread the beauty of music around the world. Anyways, I have only participated in 3 recording sessions. These recording sessions are usually well structured. All of the section leaders (and maybe more) get a set of headphones. These headphones usually only output the click track unless the conductor wants to hear back what was just recorded. Then the song is broken into sections. These sections are usually partitioned according to their difficulty. If the first 20 measures are easy for the majority of the orchestra but the next 20 are hard, we then have 2 sections: measures 1–20 and measures 20–40. We then play each section 2 or 3 times, recording each time. If there is a super obvious mistake made during the recording of a section, that recording is scrapped and we start again. If you cough, we start over. If you bump your stand, we start over. If you breathe a little to heavy, we start over. Perfection is key. Usually after the conductor feels good about a section, we will play and record it at least 1 more time as a ‘safety take’. And then after all the sections have been recorded, we play the entire song over again as one big safety take. While recording section 1, the conductor will, if played absolutely perfectly, continue onto section 2 without stopping. That way the audio editors can get the audio to mesh perfectly. It is all very well choreographed. The conductor of this orchestra once recorded a song that had a very difficult-to-reach note for the violins. So they recorded the song up to the point of that note, stopped, let all the violins find that note and hold it out, recorded a few seconds of that note, and then continued the song. I wasn’t there for that recording session but it sounded like fun. That is why it takes so long to record a song. Perfection. Any tiny mistake and the entire recording is garbage.

Recording one song can take as little time as the length of the song itself if one person is singing and playing an instrument at the same time. Add about an hour for setup and one hour to mix and master the song. Of course, if one or two microphones are positioned properly and the vocal and instrumental performance levels are spot on, you can do the song in one take. Here’s an example of one song performed by three musicians, one of them singing, in one take with two microphones. It took about an hour to get everyone in the right position. It took about half an hour to decide how much reverb and EQ to add to the original recording. Living Will - Blumleim array with two Audio Technica AT4080 Ribbon mics For a recording with multiple overdubs, the sky’s the limit for time and money.

The question is inherently flawed. It doesn’t necessarily take long to record a song at all. It all depends. For example: I can create a song from scratch in my home studio in an hour and you wouldn’t probably believe when you hear the song that it only took an hour. The recording itself is quite a simple feat nowadays. The question is how many people you have in the band / orchestra and how much processing you want to do after all the stuff has been recorded. What are your ambitions regarding the final outcome etc. So the question is actually: what are the various factors into which you can invest time and effort during the recording of a song and the answer is pretty endless. It’s all a matter of what you want to do and how you do it.

Well it depends on how clean you are with your takes and the number of instruments in your track. Each instrument are recorded in takes or sessions. Depending upon the length of the track and the no. of instruments, on an average it takes 2–3 hrs in a studio. Vocals, post processing and mastering being separate. It's wise to practice and be an ace in your takes so that you can save on studio time. Points to ponder on before hitting the studio:- Make demoPractice till your fingers bleedEquipment checkNew strings for 🎸. And they are in tune.. ofcoursePractice with a bandage on.To get perfect takes you need to practice. If you are that good then you can finish up within in 1–2 hrs excluding the fun time in studio 😜. It took me 3 hrs to do this.  It might take less for other's. Enjoy

From experience if you mean making a record, you’ll need four sessions of 8 hours each which generally means 4 days or if you have a producer and engineer working on it then you can make it in 2 days. The first session goes for instrumentation and lyric editing. The second session should be for song arrangement and mixing. The third session is for recording and editing vocals while the final session is for mixing and mastering. To achieve a great record at this pace requires a lot of concentration and professionalism…

About as long as it takes. :-) Some can be recorded in one take, with very little editing and remixing afterwards. Others need days in the studio to get all the tracks good enough to satisfy the performers and the producer and more days in the mixing and mastering suite to make sense of the results. In the case of groups like the Beatles or the Rolling Stones, some took minutes, and some took weeks.

lawyer’s answer - it depends. How finished are the song and the arrangement? Lots of hits were written in whole or in part in a studio. How many instrumentalists and singers are involved! How urgently is the label asking for it? How efficient and capable are the studio staff, engineers,players and producers? What’s your budget? There are a million factors at play.

Are you talking about a full band with instruments recording or just recording vocals over a beat / instrumental? I’m assuming the latter: I would buy a high-quality USB mic and record it at home. You can connect it to an iphone, ipad, or computer. Record the vocals with some decent onboard effects so you’ll feel in the moment, but then send the raw audio takes to me (or another audio engineer) and we will work on it over a ZOOM session together to get a professional result. You will waste a lot of time “tracking” (recording) vocals in a traditional studio and over time, a LOT of money. How would I know? Because I’ve MADE a lot of money this way. And I hate to see artists waste their already incredibly small budgets practicing singing and rapping their songs in a traditional studio. This can be done at home in a closet or, at a friends house with a closet. It can be done when you’re inspired and in the moment. You will get better takes, with more passion. This fact supersedes any benefit better equipment and a legitimate vocal booth can offer you as an artist without a large financial investor, like a record label, footing the bill. I can teach you more 😎 Free music tips & tech tricks: http://Instagram.com/mixingandmentoring

It only takes long depending on the experience of the artist and engineer. Its all bout Practice and preparation. Personally I have recorded songs in minimum 30 mins or 45 if you know you each other works and the vibe is there and your both ready at the right time to execute. I have found that if you take too long the energy is gone. so you got maximum 1 hour to lay the main parts. I have been recording and producing since i was 13 and now im 25. and recorded 2000+ songs Good Luck!

It's depend on singer. If singer learn song perfectly and sing as per requirements of music director with feel then song will record in one take around 5 to 10 minutes. Otherwise it will become lengthy process.
Depends on the recording. If you are doing one track, then you need to create the music for the rest of the tracks, a long time, possibly days. If you have everything ready, 5–10 minutes per song.
We would book a 10 hour day to record a song expected to be radio ready. Mixing would take another 10 hours. We would spend less time on the ‘filler’ songs.
